revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Mohammad-Kazem Khorasani | image = Kazem Khorasani.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = [[Mashhad]] | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Iranian<ref name="Iranica"/> | other_names = | occupation = Scholar | father = Molla Hosayn Khorasani | years_active = | known_for = "Innovator" of [[Principles of Islamic jurisprudence|osulal-feqh]]<ref name="EI3"/> | notable_works = Kefayat al-osul }}
'''Mohammad Kazem Khorasani''' or '''Akhund-e Khorasani''' ({{lang-fa|محمد کاظم خراسانی}}, (1839-1911))<ref name="Iranica">{{cite encyclopedia|last1=Hairi|first1=A.|last2=Murata|first2=S.|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/akund-molla-mohammad-kazem-korasani|title=AḴŪND ḴORĀSĀNĪ|date=1984|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Irannica}}</ref> was [[Twelver]] [[Shi'a]] [[Marja'|Marja]], politician, philosopher, reformer. He's regarded as one of the most important Shia ''[[Mujtahid]]'' at the time.<ref name="Meir"/> He was a lecturer at Najaf seminary for years and significant number of students from "different regions of the Muslim world" used to participate his lectures. His most famous work is ''The Sufficiency'' ({{lang-ar|کفایه}}) where he gathered the jurispurdential ideas such as `continuity` and "presented them in a yet more rigorous fashion as a unified theory of jurisprudence."
He is known for using his position as a [[Marja'|marja]] for political use in the [[Persian Constitutional Revolution]] (1905-1911) where he was one of the main clerical supporters of the revolution. He believed that "constitutional form of government" would be the best possible choice in the absence of [[The Twelve Imams|Imam]] and regarded the "Persian revolution" a ''[[Jihad]]'' ("holy war") in which all Muslims had to participate.
He died "suddenly" and "mysteriously", when he aimed to leave Iraq for Iran in order against support constitutionalists' resistance to the [[Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran|Anglo-Russian invasion in 1911]].
==Early life and education== Khorasani was born in [[Mashhad]] where he did his early educations. Then he left for [[Sabzevar]] at 20<ref name="EI3">{{cite encyclopedia|last1=Amir-Moezzi|first1= Mohammad Ali|url=http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-islam-3/akhund-al-khurasani-COM_23052?s.num=131&s.start=120|title=Ākhūnd al- Khurāsānī|date=2010|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Islam|edition=3rd}}</ref> where he got familiar with [[Islamic philosophy]] under [[Hadi Sabzavari|Molla Hadi Sabzavari]]. He continued Islamic philosophy under Molla Hosayn Khoʾi at the Sadr [[seminary]] in [[Tehran]],<ref name="Iranica"/> the city where he learnt [[Logic]] and Hekmat. In 1861 he moved to [[Iraq]] and in [[Najaf]] worked on complementary studies under [[Grand Ayatollah Mirza Hassan Shirazi]], famous for his campaign against [[Tobacco Protest|the tobacco concession]].<ref name="Prophet"/> Also he studied about two years under [[Morteza Ansari]].<ref name="Iranica"/> Both Morteza Ansari and Mirza Hassan Shirazi were ''[[Marja'|marja-e taqlid]]'' ("models for emulation") at the time.<ref name="EI3"/>
==Leader of Shia Muslims== Shirazi's move [[Samarra]] provided a suitable opportunity for Akhund Khorasani to show his skill in ''[[Fiqh|feqh]]'' and ''osul'' in Najaf while being supported by Shirazi. After Shirazi's death he was recognized as a "a great religious leader." Some authors such as [[Ali Davani]] and Shahrestani regard him as the "sole ''marja-e taqlid'' immediately after Shirazi." He's also regarded as "an unquestionable master of [[Principles of Islamic jurisprudence|osul al-feqh]] before [[Mohammad Fazel Sarabiani]]’s death."<ref name="Iranica"/>
He was a lecturer at Najaf seminary for years and significant number of students from "different regions of the Muslim world" used to participate his lectures.<ref name="Iranica"/> His most famous work is ''The Sufficiency'' ({{lang-ar|کفایه}}) which ranks "only after Morteza Ansari's treatice on commercial law" among the legal works written by mullahs in the last two centuries. In ''The Sufficiency'', Khorasani gathered the jurispurdential ideas such as `continuity` and "presented them in a yet more rigorous fashion as a unified theory of jurisprudence." Khorasani was not a [[sayyed]] but "owed his position almost purely to his intellectual accomplishments."<ref name="Prophet">{{cite book|last1=Mottahedeh|first1=Roy|title=The Mantle of the Prophet|publisher=Oneworld Publications|isbn=9781780747385|pages=218–219|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YlsQBwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Mantle+of+the+Prophet&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjanJjJ7obQAhVISRoKHXL6DJsQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Mantle%20of%20the%20Prophet&f=false|accessdate=1 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>
Under Khorasani's leadership, the [[Usuli]] position became the dominant view.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Acevedo|first1=Gabriel A.|last2=Shah|first2=Sarah|title=Sectarian Affiliation and Gender Traditionalism|journal=Sociology of Islam|date=25 August 2015|volume=3|issue=1-2|pages=1–29|doi=10.1163/22131418-00301001|url=http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/22131418-00301001|publisher=Brill}}{{subscription required|via=Brill}}</ref>
==Views== Although he warned the scholars for not involving in political activities as he believed that they had other responsibilities, he believed that scholars could act as "warning voices in society" and criticize the officials who were not doing their responsibilities correctly. He compared the role of scholars with "[[salt]] of the earth" in the sense that they prevent "decay of power", should fight against injustice and that they are against "[[autocratic]] attitudes"<ref name="Religion">{{cite book|last1=Hustinx|first1=Lesley|last2=Essen|first2=Johan Von|last3=Haers|first3=Jacques|last4=Mels|first4=Sara|title=Religion and Volunteering: Complex, contested and ambiguous relationships|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783319045856|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FsokBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA73&dq=akhund+khorasani&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwje3sXWmp3QAhXDBcAKHWbqB-QQ6AEIMDAD#v=onepage&q=akhund%20khorasani&f=false|accessdate=10 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>
==Political activities== The first known Akhund Khorasani's anti-government political activities is related to "the unrest following the two Russian loans to [[Mozaffar-al-din Shah]]."<ref name="Iranica"/>
Mohammad Kazem Khorasani was also one of the main clerical supporters of the [[Iranian Constitutional Revolution]]<ref name="Iranica"/> and along with [[Mirza Hosayn Tehrani]] and [[Shaikh Abdallah Mazandarani]] he led people against what they called a "state tyranny"<ref name="Kamali">{{cite book|last1=Kamali|first1=Mohammad Hashim|last2=Ramadan|first2=Tariq|title=The Middle Path of Moderation in Islam: The Quranic Principle of Wasatiyyah|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190226831|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HffzCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA109&lpg=PA109&dq=Mirza+Hosayn+Tehrani&source=bl&ots=PRtXZUkIgK&sig=8Fmq_0kOJidZE2LDy-2Lykx1nrQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjavv2v04rQAhXJShQKHTaTAzUQ6AEIODAJ#v=onepage&q=Mirza%20Hosayn%20Tehrani&f=false|accessdate=2 November 2016|language=en}}</ref> and issued fatwas and "sent telegrams to tribal chiefs, prominent national and political leaders, and heads of state in England, France, Germany, and Turkey." When [[Mohammad Ali Shah]] became king of Iran, Mohammad Kazem Khorasani sent him a "ten-point" instruction including points on ptotecting Islam, promoting domestic industries and modern science, stopping foreign powers' intervention in Iran "while retaining diplomatic relations", and establishing "justice and equality".<ref name="Iranica"/>
He believed that "constitutional form of government" would be the best possible choice in the absence of [[The Twelve Imams|Imam]] and regarded the "Persian revolution" a ''[[Jihad]]'' ("holy war") in which all Muslims had to participate.<ref name="Iranica"/> When [[Sheikh Fazlollah Noori]] declared journalists non-Muslims for their support of the new Constitutional Assembly, Khorasani retaliated by announcing that Sheikh Fazlollah was himself no longer a Muslim, leading to Fazlollah's execution.<ref name="Prophet"/>{{rp|222}} The reaction to Noori's execution in Najaf harmed Khorasani and other constitution supporters and led to a rivalry with [[Mohammed Kazem Yazdi]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Turban for the Crown|author=Said Amir Arjomand|year=1989|publisher=Oxford University Press US |isbn=0-19-504258-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IQci1YIffjYC&pg=PA52&lpg=PA52&dq=kazem+yazdi&source=web&ots=yrH7tQXGrg&sig=32ED0rTwHhjLFzoG8lHLCU0HWTk&hl=en }}</ref> Khorsani acted more intensively against Mohammad Ali Shah when he shelled the parliament building and executed many "constitutionalists".<ref name="Iranica"/>
He apparently did not have ties with [[Oudh Bequest]] nor he favored British, despite the allegations. He were in an "equal opposition" to Russia and Britain, two powers at the time.<ref name="EI2">{{cite encyclopedia|last1=Hairi|first1=Abdul-Hadi|url=http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-islam-2/khurasani-SIM_4337?s.num=17&s.au=%22Hairi%2C+Abdul+Hadi%22|title=K̲h̲urāsānī|date=|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Islam|edition=2nd}}</ref>
==Works and pupils== He authored many books hence titled "Innovator" (''al-mujaddid'') of ''Usul al-feqh''. Kifayat al-usul, Khorasani's most important book, is taught in advanced classes at the seminaries as the main text on the methodology of law. It has received "hundreds of commentaries".<ref name="EI3"/> The book suppressed ''Qvanin al-Osul'' by Qummi, one of seminary main texts taught at sotuh level.<ref name="Meir">{{cite book|last1=Litvak|first1=Meir|title=Shi'i Scholars of Nineteenth-Century Iraq: The 'Ulama' of Najaf and Karbala'|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521892964|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3pYRFQQG5kEC&pg=PA92&dq=akhund+khorasani&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwje3sXWmp3QAhXDBcAKHWbqB-QQ6AEIKjAC#v=onepage&q=akhund%20khorasani&f=false|accessdate=10 November 2016|language=en}}</ref> Also, he wrote one of the most important commentaries on [[Morteza Ansari|Shaykh Morteza al-Ansari]]'s ''Durar al-fawaid fi sharh al-Faraid'', also taught alongside Kifayat al-usul.<ref name="EI3"/>
[[Ayatollah Mirza Hussein Naini]], [[Muhammad Hossein Qaravi|Ayatollah Muhammad Hossein Qaravi]], [[Agha Zia Addin Araghi]] were among his students.<ref name="EI3"/>
==Death== He died "suddenly" and "mysteriously", when he aimed to leave Iraq for Iran in order against support constitutionalists' resistance to the [[Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran|Anglo-Russian invasion in 1911]].<ref name="EI3"/>
== See also == *[[Iranian Constitutional Revolution]] *[[Intellectual movements in Iran]] *[[Mirza Malkom Khan]] *[[Ayatollah Mirza Hussein Naini|Mirza Hussein Naini]] *[[Oudh Bequest]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Mohammad-Kazem Khorasani}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130302232751/http://akhondekhorasani.ir/Portal/Home/ Official Website]
{{Persian Constitutional Revolution Persions}} {{Authority control}}

{{Infobox scientist | image = Alwyn Gentry in August 1968.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Alwyn Gentry in August 1968. | birth_date = {{Birth date|1945|01|06}} | birth_place = [[Clay Center, Kansas]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1993|08|03|1945|01|06}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | citizenship = United States | nationality = United States | fields = [[Botany]] | workplaces = | alma_mater = [[Kansas State University]] (BA, BS)
[[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] (MS)
[[Washington University in St. Louis]] (Ph.D.) | thesis_title = An Eco-evolutionary Study of the Bignoniaceae of South Central America | thesis_url = | thesis_year = 1972 | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = Flora of tropical forests;
Gentry Forest Transect | author_abbrev_bot = A.H.Gentry | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | spouse = }} '''Alwyn Howard Gentry''' (6 January 1945 – 3 August 1993) was an American botanist and plant collector, who made major contributions to the understanding of the vegetation of tropical forests. ==Education== Gentry was born on 6 January 1945 in [[Clay Center, Kansas]], and received his schooling at the [[List of high schools in Kansas#Clay County|Clay Center Community High School]], from which he graduated in 1963. He graduated from [[Kansas State University]] in 1967 with a B.A. in physical science and a B.S. in botany and zoology. He earned his master's degree in 1969 at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] as a student of botanist [[Hugh Iltis]], with a thesis on the genus ''[[Tabebuia]]'' ([[Bignoniaceae]]) of Central America, a subject which he continued to study at [[Washington University in St. Louis]], Missouri, from which he received his doctorate in 1972, with a Ph.D. thesis entitled ''An Eco-evolutionary Study of the Bignoniaceae of South Central America''.{{cite journal|last=Miller|first=James S|first2=Theodore M |last2=Barkley |first3=Hugh H |last3=Iltis |first4=Walter H |last4=Lewis |first5=Enrique |last5=Forero |first6=Mark |last6=Plotkin |first7=Oliver |last7=Phillips |first8=Ricardo |last8=Rueda |first9=Peter H |last9=Raven|year=1996|title=Alwyn Howard Gentry, 1945-1993: A Tribute|journal=Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden|volume=83|issue=4|pages=433–60|jstor=2399988}} ==Career== Gentry spent his entire working career at the [[Missouri Botanical Garden]], starting as an assistant curator in October 1972. In 1974, he made his first visit to Peru, a country that became the major focus of much of his subsequent work; he made his second trip there in 1976 and by the time of his death had visited the country 33 times. He also maintained his interest in the Bignoniaceae: he contributed treatments of the family to nine volumes, including the ''Flora of Panama'', and had a further five in press when he died. One of Gentry's major innovations was the use of transect samples as a tool for assessing the composition and structure of tropical forests, known as the [[Gentry Forest Transect]]. His method, allied to his encyclopedic knowledge of tropical plants, allowed him to sample a site in a matter of days, and over the course of his career he amassed data from over 200 such transects worldwide. Alwyn Gentry was prolific both as an author and as a plant collector: he published over 200 works and had many more on hand at the time of his death; and he collected over 80,000 plant specimens, hundreds of which have proved to be species new to science. Because many of the plants that he encountered during his transect sampling were not flowering, Gentry developed the ability to identify species from vegetative specimens, not just from flowers and fruits, an ability that led to the publication of his ''Field Guide to the Families and Genera of Woody Plants of Northwest South America'',{{cite journal|jstor=2996602|title=Reviewed Work: ''A Field Guide to the Families of Woody Plants of Northwest South America'' by A. H. Gentry|author=Gonzalez, Favio|journal=Journal of the Torrey Botanical Society|volume=124|issue=1|year=1997|pages=98–100|doi=10.2307/2996602}} completed just months before his death. In 1990, [[Conservation International]] established a Rapid Assessment Program (RAP) to undertake quick assessments of areas deemed to be significant for conservation. Gentry's transect method was well suited to such work and he became increasingly involved as a member of the RAP team. ==Death== On 3 August 1993, Alwyn Gentry was on a RAP mission in western Ecuador, when the light aircraft in which he was travelling crashed into a mountain ridge near [[Guayaquil]]. Four people—the pilot, Gentry, American ornithologist [[Theodore A. Parker III]], and Ecuadorian ecologist Eduardo Aspiazu—died in the crash; three other researchers survived. Parker and Gentry are memorialized in the annual Parker/Gentry Award for Conservation Biology of the [[Field Museum of Natural History]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fieldmuseum.org/research_collections/ecp/ecp_sites/Parker_Gentry/award.htm|title=Parker/Gentry Award for Conservation Biology|year=2007|publisher=The Field Museum|accessdate=27 October 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090317192904/http://www.fieldmuseum.org/research_collections/ecp/ecp_sites/Parker_Gentry/award.htm|archive-date=2009-03-17|dead-url=yes|df=}} Several plant species have been named after Gentry, including: ''[[Acidocroton gentryi]], [[Citharexylum gentryi]], [[Crossothamnus gentryi]], [[Eleutherodactylus gentryi]], [[Hedyosmum gentryi]], [[Metalepis gentryi]], [[Palicourea gentryi]], [[Phyllanthus gentryi]], [[Sobralia gentryi]]'' and ''[[Zamia gentryi]]'', as well as a bird, ''[[Herpsilochmus gentryi]]''. In several instances, Gentry had been involved in the collection of the [[type specimen]]s of these plants.{{cite book|last=[[Loran Whitelock|Whitelock]]|first=Loran M|title=The Cycads|year=2002|publisher=[[Timber Press]]|location=Portland, OR|isbn=0-88192-522-5|pages=304–5}}{{cite journal|last=Téllez-Valdés|first=Oswaldo|year=1996|title=Two new species of Dioscorea (Dioscoreaceae) from Peru|journal=Brittonia|publisher=[[New York Botanical Garden]]|volume=48|issue=1|pages=100–103|doi=10.2307/2807670}}{{cite journal|last=D'Arcy|first=W G|author2=Ronald L Liesner|year=1981|title=Hedyosmum (Chloranthaceae) in Panama|journal=Systematic Botany|publisher=[[American Society of Plant Taxonomists]]|volume=6|issue=1|pages=74–86|jstor=2418637|doi=10.2307/2418637}} {{Botanist|A.H.Gentry|Gentry, Alwyn Howard}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gentry, Alwyn Howard}} [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:American botanists]] [[Category:Kansas State University alumni]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison College of Agricultural and Life Sciences alumni]] [[Category:Victims of aviation accidents or incidents in Ecuador]] [[Category:Washington University in St. Louis alumni]] [[Category:Missouri Botanical Garden people]] [[Category:20th-century botanists]] [[Category:People from Clay Center, Kansas]] [[Category:20th-century American scientists]]

[[File:Frans Snyders - Still Life with a Wine Cooler - Google Art Project.jpg|thumbnail|325px|[[Frans Snyders]] – ''Still Life with a Wine Cooler'']] [[Image:Eagle Jacquemart Palais Garnier.jpg|thumb|right|165px|Eagle by [[Henri Alfred Jacquemart]] on the [[Palais Garnier|Paris Garnier Opera]]]] [[File:JulesMoigniez-bronze.jpg|thumb|right|165px|A bronze sculpture of a partridge with gilt patination by [[Jules Moigniez]], c. 1880]]
An '''animalier''' is an [[artist]], mainly from the 19th century, who specializes in, or is known for, skill in the realistic portrayal of [[animal]]s. "[[Animal painter]]" is the more general term for earlier artists. Although the work may be in any genre or format, the term is most often applied to [[sculptors]] and [[painters]].
'''''Animalier''''' as a collective plural noun, or '''''animalier bronzes''''', is also a term in [[antiques]] for small-scale sculptures of animals, of which large numbers were produced, often mass-produced, primarily in 19th-century [[France]] and to a lesser extent elsewhere in continental Europe.
Although many earlier examples can be found, animalier sculpture became more popular, and reputable, in early 19th-century [[Paris]] with the works of [[Antoine-Louis Barye]] (1795–1875), for whom the term was coined, derisively, by critics in 1831,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/animalier-sculpture-1 |title="Animalier sculpture." ''The Concise Grove Dictionary of Art''. Oxford University Press, Inc., 2002. Answers.com 13 April 2008 |publisher=Answers.com |date= |access-date=23 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~iuam/online_modules/metz/collection.html |title=Dr. Arthur R. Metz and His Collection |publisher=Indiana.edu |date= |access-date=23 August 2012}}</ref> and of [[Émile-Coriolan Guillemin]]. By the mid-century, a taste for animal subjects was very widespread among all sections of the middle-classes.
In [[French language|French]], a ''parc animalier'' is a [[zoo]].
==Prominent animaliers== {{see also|Category:Animal artists}}
===Painters=== * [[Richard Ansdell]] * [[Rosa Bonheur]] * [[Jacques Raymond Brascassat]] * [[Alexandre-François Desportes]] * [[Melchior d'Hondecoeter]] * [[Charles Jacque]] * [[Paul Jouve]] * [[Edwin Landseer]]

{{Infobox person |name = Bernard Carr |image = Bernard-carr.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |alma_mater = [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] (BA)
[[Institute of Astronomy, Cambridge]] (PhD) |occupation = Professor of mathematics and astronomy }} '''Bernard J. Carr''' is a British [[professor]] of [[mathematics]] and [[astronomy]] at [[Queen Mary University of London]] (QMUL). His research interests include the early universe, dark matter, [[general relativity]], [[primordial black hole]]s, and the [[anthropic principle]]. ==Education== He completed his BA in mathematics in 1972 at [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]]. For his doctorate, obtained in 1976, he studied relativity and cosmology under [[Stephen Hawking]] at the [[Institute of Astronomy, Cambridge|Institute of Astronomy]] in Cambridge. He was the president of the [[Cambridge University Buddhist Society]] and was friends with [[Ajahn Brahm]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PR0w_6F8xDs#t=19m50s |title=Ajahn Brahm reminisces life at Cambridge and Bernard Carr}} ==Academic career== In 1976 he was elected to a Fellowship at Trinity and he also became an advanced [[Science and Engineering Research Council|SERC]] fellow at the Institute of Astronomy. In 1979 he was awarded a Lindemann Fellowship for post-doctoral research in America and spent a year working in various universities there. In 1980 he took up a Senior Research Fellowship at the Institute of Astronomy in Cambridge. In 1985 he moved to the then Queen Mary College, University of London, where he is now Professor of Mathematics and Astronomy. He has held visiting professorships at [[Kyoto University]], [[University of Tokyo|Tokyo University]] and the [[Fermilab|Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory]], and is a frequent visitor to other institutes in America and Canada. He is the author of more than two hundred scientific papers and his monograph, ''Cosmological Gravitational Waves'', won the 1985 [[Adams Prize|Adams Essay Prize]]. ==Interests outside academia== He has interests outside physics, including [[Psychic researcher|psychic research]]."Can Psychical Research Bridge the Gulf Between Matter and Mind?" Bernard Carr ''Proceedings of the Society for Psychical Research'', Vol 59 Part 221 June 2008 He has been a member of the [[Society for Psychical Research]] (SPR) for thirty years, serving as its Education Officer and the Chairman of its Research Activities Committee for various periods. He was President of the SPR from 2000 to 2004. He is also a Director of Scientific and Medical Network (SMN) in the UK. He has been the co-holder of a grant from the [[John Templeton Foundation]] for a project entitled ''Fundamental Physics and the Problem of our Existence''. He is the editor of a book based on a series of conferences funded by the Foundation, entitled ''Universe or Multiverse?'' Bernard Carr also made an appearance in the documentary film ''[[The Trouble with Atheism]]'', where he discussed these concepts, and also appeared in the science documentary film ''Target...Earth?'' (1980). == Publications == * Bernard Carr (ed.): ''Universe or Multiverse?'' Cambridge University Press, 2007, {{ISBN|978-0-521-84841-1}} == Media == *In 2014, featured in "[[The Principle]]", a documentary examining the [[Copernican Principle]].https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2458876/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/people/academic-staff?q=people/personal-profile/&id=342 Page at QMUL] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carr, Bernard}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Academics of Queen Mary University of London]] [[Category:California Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Fellows of Trinity College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Members of the Eurasian Astronomical Society]] [[Category:Parapsychologists]]

{{third-party|date=August 2018}} '''Brenda Darden Wilkerson''' is President and CEO of [[AnitaB.org|Anitab.org]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://anitab.org/profiles/meet-new-ceo-brenda-darden-wilkerson/|title=Meet Brenda Darden Wilkerson, AnitaB.org President & CEO - AnitaB.org|date=2017-09-20|work=AnitaB.org|access-date=2018-08-23|language=en-US}}</ref> Prior to Anitab.org, Wilkerson founded the "Computer Science for All" Initiative and was Director of Computer Science Education for [[Chicago Public Schools]]. She holds a computer science degree from [[Northwestern University]].
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wilkerson, Brenda}} [[Category:American women chief executives]] [[Category:Northwestern University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Nationality missing]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Candice Warner | birth_name = Candice Ann Falzon | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1985|03|13}} | birth_place = [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]] | nationality = Australian | spouse = {{marriage|[[David Warner (cricketer)|David Warner]]|2015}} | children = 2 | occupation = Model }} '''Candice Ann Warner (née Falzon)''' is a retired Australian professional ironwoman, surf life saver and model.
== Ironwoman ==
Warner first competed professionally at the age of 14 in the [[Ironman (surf lifesaving)|Ironman]] series.<ref>[http://www.sportsbureau.com.au/profiles/107.htm Motivational Speeches | Brand Ambassadors<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> At 16 she was a NSW state ironwoman champion.<ref name="GoldCoast">{{cite news|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2007/10/11/3662_gold-coast-lead-story.html|title=Coach joins Coolangatta Gold catfight|date=11 October 2007|work=goldcoast.com.au|accessdate=10 June 2008}}</ref> In January 2008 Warner qualified for a spot in the 2008 [[Kellogg's Nutri-Grain Ironman Series|Nutri-Grain Ironman & Ironwoman Series]].<ref>[http://surfsports.slsa.com.au/default.aspx?s=mediarelease&id=671 Surf Lifesaving Australia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080610025956/http://surfsports.slsa.com.au/default.aspx?s=mediarelease&id=671 |date=10 June 2008 }}, New faces for Kellogg's Nutri-Grain Ironman Series</ref>
== TV work ==
Warner appeared on the 2008 series of [[It Takes Two (Australian TV series)|''It Takes Two'']],<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,23032448-5001021,00.html The Daily Telegraph] It Takes Two: Candice Falzon gets it in the can</ref> supporting the [[Beyond Blue]] charity but was eliminated sixth on 1 April 2008. Her mentor was [[Anthony Callea]].
She was the subject of the [[Australian Story]] program on 9 June 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/austory/specials/shownomercy/default.htm|title=Show No Mercy|date=9 June 2008|work=[[Australian Story]]|publisher=[[ABC Television]]|accessdate=10 June 2008}}</ref>
In 2017, Warner appeared as a celebrity contestant on the [[Hell's Kitchen Australia|Australian version]] of ''[[Hell's Kitchen (UK TV series)|Hell's Kitchen]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/tv/reality-tv/the-celebrities-taking-on-marco-pierre-white-in-hells-kitchen-australia-are-named/news-story/52082c434d4a7d30fb2994d6609fffee|title=The celebrities taking on Marco Pierre White in Hell’s Kitchen Australia are named|date=24 March 2017|accessdate=24 March 2017|first=Amelia|last=Saw|work=news.com.au}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/page-13-hells-kitchen-australia-host-doesnt-know-the-celebrity-contestants/news-story/31a8e241db2b763cb97bb4258e34c701|title=Hell’s Kitchen Australia host doesn’t know the celebrity contestants|date=24 March 2017|accessdate=24 March 2017|first=Alice|last=Coster|work=Herald Sun}}</ref>
She came in tenth place, being the first one eliminated.
==Personal life==
Warner was born in [[Sydney]], in the suburb of [[Cronulla]]. Warner is of [[Malta|Maltese]] heritage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rleague.com/db/article.php?id=22361 |title=Candice Falzon in Search 2005 Miss Malta Knight |last=Micallef |first=Anthony |date=28 February 2005 |work=Rleague.com |accessdate=27 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150411030233/http://rleague.com/db/article.php?id=22361 |archivedate=11 April 2015 }}</ref> She is the wife of Australian cricketer [[David Warner (cricketer)|David Warner]].<ref name="dailymail.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3026371/Newlyweds-David-Candice-Warner-picture-wedded-bliss-cricketer-shares-snap-dinner-revealing-Falzon-changed-surname.html|title=David Warner and Candice are a picture of wedded bliss in Sydney - Daily Mail Online|work=Mail Online}}</ref> They married in April 2015.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk"/> They had their first child (a daughter) on 11 September 2014<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gamble|first1=Livia|title=It's an 'Ashes baby' for David Warner and Candice Falzon|url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/celebrity/its-an-ashes-baby-for-david-warner-and-candice-falzon-20140912-10ftmf.html|accessdate=12 September 2014|work=smh.com.au|issue=12 September 2014}}</ref> and a second daughter on 14 January 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lian|first1=Jotham|title=Candice and David Warner announce birth of baby daughter Indi Rae|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/cricket/candice-and-david-warner-announce-birth-of-baby-indi-rae-20160113-gm5j4w.html|work=smh.com.au|date=14 January 2016}}</ref> They live in Sydney.
== Controversy == On March 4, 2018, during tea in the 1st Test between [[Australian cricket team in South Africa in 2017–18|Australia and South Africa]] in Durban, Warner’s husband was involved in a heated exchange with South African Wicket-Keeper [[Quinton de Kock]] regarding vulgar comments about her.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22648767/david-warner-involved-heated-exchange-quinton-de-kock|title=Warner involved in heated exchange with de Kock|last=|first=|date=|work=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> David Warner fired back at De Kock and was forcibly restrained by teammates [[Usman Khawaja]] and [[Steve Smith (cricketer)|Steve Smith]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/sport/cricket/david-warner-shown-in-fiery-confrontation-with-quinton-de-kock-20180305-p4z2t9.html|title=David Warner shown in fiery confrontation with Quinton de Kock|last=Barrett|first=Chris|date=2018-03-05|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=27 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22673885/david-warner-contest-charge-quinton-de-kock-does|title=David Warner doesn't contest charge, but de Kock does|last=|first=|date=|work=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/cricket/2018/03/05/icc-investigate-ugly-off-field-row-david-warner-quinton-de-kock/|title=ICC to investigate ugly off-field row between David Warner and Quinton de Kock|last=Hoult|first=Nick|date=2018-03-05|work=The Telegraph|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
In March 2018 Warner’s husband was suspected of involvement in a [[2018 Australian ball tampering scandal|ball tampering scandal]] during the [[Australian cricket team in South Africa in 2017–18#3rd_Test|3rd Test match between South Africa and Australia]] along with skipper Steve Smith and Cameron Bancroft; several former and current international cricketers have accused the Australian cricket team of cheating.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/cricket/ball-tampering-row-steve-smith-david-warner-could-face-life-bans-by-cricket-australia-report/story-zYL4Jf1HRB77krxcjwEQNI.html|title=Ball-tampering row: Steve Smith, David Warner could face life bans by Cricket Australia - report|last=|first=|date=2018-03-25|work=www.hindustantimes.com|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/cricket/australia-in-south-africa/australian-captain-vice-captain-step-down-after-ball-tampering/articleshow/63457776.cms|title=Life ban for Smith, Warner? CA may announce 'exemplary punishment' - Times of India ►|last=|first=|date=|work=The Times of India|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Warner exchanged a war of words with former English cricket captain, [[Michael Vaughan]] over Twitter regarding comments posted by him about David Warner's complaint about personal abuse from the South African crowd during the second day of the test match after his dismissal, and Warner's attitude to the ball tampering controversy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5547397/Candice-Warner-slammed-Twitter-husband-Davids-involvement-cricket-ball-tampering-scandal.html|title=Candice Warner slammed on Twitter over ball tampering scandal|last=|first=|date=|work=Mail Online|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/sport/cricket/candice-warner-in-twitter-row-with-exengland-captain-michael-vaughan-over-personal-abuse/news-story/945da220f04c078a185e3ea1026eb2e2|title=Candice fires up over star’s claim|last=|first=|date=|work=NewsComAu|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://i.stuff.co.nz/sport/cricket/102626725/candice-warner-sparks-twitter-row-with-michael-vaughan-over-personal-abuse-of-aussies|title=Candice Warner sparks Twitter row with Michael Vaughan over 'personal abuse' of Aussies|last=|first=|date=|work=Stuff|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sports.ndtv.com/cricket/david-warners-wife-involved-in-war-of-words-on-twitter-with-former-england-captain-michael-vaughan-1829179|title=David Warner's Wife Involved In War Of Words On Twitter With Former England Captain Michael Vaughan – NDTV Sports|last=NDTVSports.com|first=|date=|work=NDTVSports.com|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Warner, Candice}} [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Australian female models]] [[Category:Models from Sydney]] [[Category:Australian surf lifesavers]] [[Category:Australian people of Maltese descent]] [[Category:Australian female swimmers]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:Participants in Australian reality television series]]

revision.comment: Removing [[:c:File:CTH_Photo_Shoot_1.jpg|CTH_Photo_Shoot_1.jpg]], it has been deleted from Commons by [[:c:User:Racconish|Racconish]] because: Missing [[:c:COM:EI|essential information]] such as [[:c:COM:L|license]], [[:c:COM:PERMISSION|permission]] or so
revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Christon Gray | background = solo_singer | image = Christon_Gray_Piano_Video_Shoot_in_New_York_September_2015.jpg | image_size = | birth_name = Christon Michael Gray | alias = Flow Jackson | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1986|7|18|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Columbus, Ohio]], U.S. | origin = Columbus, Ohio U.S. | death_date = | genre = [[Contemporary R&B]], [[Christian hip hop]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]], [[rapper]], [[Record producer|producer]] | instrument = [[Vocals]], [[Piano]] | years_active = {{start date|2006}}–present | associated_acts = Kirk Franklin, [[Taelor Gray]], [[W.L.A.K.]], [[JGivens]], The Elevationists | website = {{URL|christongray.com}} | Former Labels = Fo Yo Soul/RCA, Collision Records }}
'''Christon Michael Gray''' (born July 18, 1986) is an [[United States|American]] [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] [[Singing|singer]] and [[Rapping|rapper]] born and raised in [[Columbus, Ohio]]. He is a [[Christian]] and calls his music ‘about being human’. It’s this approach that has allowed him to be successful as a mainstream artist.
==Background== Gray was born Christon Michael Gray on July 18, 1986, in [[Columbus, Ohio]]. His parents, Arthur Gray (a former choir leader), and his mother Leigh Ann (a trained [[soprano]]) have two other children; Christon’s older brother, [[Taelor Gray]], who is also a rapper and [[pastor]], and his younger sister Aubrey, who is currently a college student. He resides in Columbus and has a daughter named Mya Blue.
==Music career==
=== 2006 - 11: Elevationists & EWEWM ===
In 2006, Gray was a part of The Elevationists with his brother, Taelor and childhood friend BJ (James Hazley). After a few years together, they disbanded the group.
In 2011, Gray, with the help of writing partner and music director Marlo Scott, released an album entitled ''[[Even With Evil With Me]].'' The independent release spawned the timeless track ‘Isle of You’, which quickly led to record label interest. Before the year was out, he was signed to Collision Records.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newreleasetoday.com/albumdetail.php?album_id=13892|title=School Of Roses by Christon Gray {{!}} CD Reviews And Information {{!}} NewReleaseToday|website=www.newreleasetoday.com|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref>
=== 2012 – 14: Collision Records & School of Roses === In 2012, he began working on his retail and label debut for Collision, but as it morphed, he decided to release it as a free mixtape.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rapzilla.com/rz/music/freemp3s/5063-christon-gray-body-art|title=Christon Gray 'Body Art'|last=Horton|first=Chad|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref> ''Body Art'' was a hit among Gray's fans and featured the label's roster as well as other artists and producers from the [[Christian hip hop|CHH]] genre. It caught many fans off guard because it was more of a rap album than EWEWM, which was the album’s intention.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wadeoradio.com/christon-gray-body-art-putting-the-art-back-in-artist/|title=Christon Gray "Body Art" – Putting the 'Art' back in Artist|date=2012-09-28|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref>
Early in 2013, the label released the collective album [[W.L.A.K. (album)|''We Live As Kings (W.L.A.K.)'''''.''']] As a member of the four-man group, Christon was featured on the majority of the tracks. The album went on to top the [[Billboard charts|Billboard]] Gospel chart and crack the top 10 on the Rap and Christian charts. It also contained the cut '[[The Glory Album|King In Me]]' which was used as the theme song to [[American Idol]]’s [[Super Bowl]] commercial in 2014.<ref>{{Citation|last=Christon Gray|title=American Idol Superbowl Ad (2014) ft. 'King In Me' by Swoope and Christon Gray|date=2015-03-30|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oxbDZ8Irfo8|accessdate=2016-08-23}}</ref>
On March 25, 2014, Gray released his 2nd studio album entitled ''[[School of Roses]]''. It included fan favorites ‘[[School of Roses|Vanish]]’ (feat. [[Swoope]]) and ‘[[School of Roses|Wanna]]’ (feat. [[JGivens]]) which peaked at #15 on the [[Billboard charts|Billboard]] Live Trending chart. This was more of an R&B album than ''Body Art'', and it debuted at the top of the overall charts on [[iTunes]], and hit #44 on the [[Billboard Top 200]] and #5 on Top R&B Albums.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christongray.com/promo/|title=PROMO|website=CHRISTON GRAY|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref>
=== 2015 - January 2017: FYS/RCA & The Glory Album === In early 2015, Gray began releasing music on his own, prompting fans to question whether or not he was still a part of Collision and [[W.L.A.K.]] The first track [[The Glory Album|'Open Door (See You Later)']] was posted on his [[SoundCloud|Soundcloud]] page in March of 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wadeoradio.com/new-music-christon-gray-open-door-see-you-later/|title=New Music: Christon Gray - "Open Door (See You Later)"|date=2015-03-20|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref> Still not addressing his status, one week later he posted the beautiful piano led love ballad, [[The Glory Album|'Afraid With You']]. Lastly, he posted ‘Light On’ featuring [[B.Reith]] the following week. On April 28, 2015, after confirming he was leaving Collision in an interview with Wade-O<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wadeoradio.com/christon-gray-talks-leaving-collision-the-demos-drops-new-freestyle/|title=Christon Gray Talks Leaving Collision & 'The Demos' + Drops New Freestyle|date=2015-04-09|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref> & [[Rapzilla]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rapzilla.com/rz/news/38-backstage/10579-christon-gray-pens-open-letter-about-collision-records-departure-announces-ep|title=Christon Gray announces departure from Collision Records, new EP|last=Daniels|first=David|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref> Gray released an EP called ''The Demos'' to be streamed exclusively on the Christian music-streaming app, "The Overflow<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://theoverflow.com/blog/christon-gray-to-release-exclusive-ep-on-theoverflow/|title=Christon Gray to release EXCLUSIVE EP on TheOverflow! - TheOverflow.com: Streaming Christian Music|date=2015-04-07|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref>". The album went to be the most streamed project on the entire service for 2015, with all 5 tracks occupying spots #1 - #5 the week of its release.
It became clear that he was using these songs to get himself a new record deal, and in June 2015, he revealed that he had signed with [[Kirk Franklin|Kirk Franklin's]] label, Fo Yo Soul Recordings/[[RCA Records|RCA]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://christongray.com/|title=BLOG|website=CHRISTON GRAY|access-date=2016-08-23}}</ref> Kirk himself made the announcement via video screen at ''Alive Fest'' in Ohio on June 20, 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gospelpundit.com/2015/06/kirk-franklin-signs-singerrapper-christon-gray-to-fo-yo-soul-recordings/|title=Kirk Franklin Signs Singer/Rapper Christon Gray to Fo Yo Soul Recordings|date=2015-06-23|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref> He subsequently removed ''The Demos'' to work on his third retail album and label debut.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://christongray.com/|title=BLOG|website=CHRISTON GRAY|access-date=2016-08-23}}</ref>
On November 18, 2015, [[Rapzilla|Rapzilla.com]] released an interview via email with Gray in which he said his debut with Fo Yo Soul had been completed and was being scheduled for release during "the colder part of 2016".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rapzilla.com/rz/features/interviews/12000-christon-gray-talks-upcoming-album-kirk-franklin-and-says-he-has-a-song-called-50-shades|title=Christon Gray talks upcoming album, Kirk Franklin and says he has a song called '50 Shades'|last=Daniels|first=David|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref>
A couple weeks later, on December 2, 2015, Gray released a freestyle video that included the name and release date of his next project, ''[[The Glory Album]]''. Gray's debut album with Fo Yo Soul/RCA was set to be released on March 11, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rapzilla.com/rz/news/38-backstage/12079-christon-gray-reveals-release-date-of-new-album-alongside-freestyle|title=Christon Gray reveals release date of new album alongside freestyle|last=Daniels|first=David|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref>
Two weeks after that, he debuted the first new track off the album on [[Vevo]] called ‘[[The Glory Album|Connor McDees]]’ featuring [[Brooklyn]] emcee, [[Skyzoo]] and his brother Taelor.
Leading up to the album release, he was chosen as one of [[ESPN]]'''’'''s Artists of the Month for March.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/music/post/_/id/8711/march-music-of-the-month-on-espn|title=March Music of the Month on ESPN!|access-date=2016-08-23}}</ref> The station highlighted 3 tracks, ‘[[The Glory Album|Open Door (See You Later)]]’, '[[The Glory Album|The Glory Pt. I]]' and ‘[[Stop Me (Christon Gray Song)|Stop Me]]' on all of their regular programing. The later track went on to be used in commercials for [[Honda]],<ref>{{Citation|last=Honda|title=Another Milestone - 2016 Honda Civic Coupe :30|date=2016-05-06|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tc_vRpmZT0E|accessdate=2016-09-14}}</ref> [[HBO]]’s [[Ballers]],<ref>{{Citation|last=HBO|title=Ballers Season Two: Episode #2 Preview (HBO)|date=2016-07-17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4sRvnivFbbg|accessdate=2016-09-14}}</ref> [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]'s [[Lethal Weapon (TV series)|Lethal Weapon]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/search?q=Riggs%20&%20Murtaugh%20are%20always%20on%20their%20best%20behavior.%20Buckle%20up%20for%20the%20#LethalWeapon%20premiere%20Wednesday%20on%20@FOXTV!&src=typd|title=Riggs - Twitter Search|website=twitter.com|language=en|access-date=2017-04-24}}</ref> & [[Roc Nation Sports|RocNation Sports]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BIf3p8QAXZ9/?taken-by=rocnationsports|title=Instagram video by Roc Nation Sports • Jul 30, 2016 at 7:50pm UTC|website=Instagram|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref> It was also used at the [[ESPY Award]]s during the shows final segment.<ref>{{Citation|last=Team USA Live|title=ESPYS 2016 - LeBron James Wins Best Male Athlete|date=2016-07-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xowR2chp8NI|accessdate=2016-09-14}}</ref> The remix of the song was debuted during his interview on the [[Sway Calloway|Sway in the Morning]] show in mid September 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://swaysuniverse.com/christon-gray-on-christian-groupies-marriage-challenges-racial-injustice-5-fingers-of-death/|title=Christon Gray on Christian-Groupies, Marriage Challenges, Racial Injustice + 5 Fingers of Death – Sways Universe|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en-US}}</ref> The song continued success in 2017, being used on [[FOX Sports]] programming worldwide, as well as the team song for a number of professional sports franchises. In 2018, the song was used as the theme to [[Warner Bros. Pictures|Warner Bros Pictures]] blockbuster '[[Rampage (2018 film)|Rampage]]'<ref>{{Citation|last=Warner Bros. Pictures|title=RAMPAGE - OFFICIAL TRAILER 2 [HD]|date=2018-02-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-43MBOJnVks&t=17s|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref> starring [[Dwayne Johnson|The Rock]] and as the intro song to [[EA Sports]] '[[Madden NFL 19|Madden '19]]' [[National Football League|NFL]] Video game<ref>{{Citation|last=CurtWork|title=MADDEN NFL 19 ANTONIO BROWN INTRO [STOP ME] [CHRISTON GRAY]|date=2018-08-06|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qr6MN7uUp_8|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref>. For the 2018-19 [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] Season, ESPN is using the song for it's in NBA Studio show.
Also during this time, [[Apple Music]] selected ‘[[The Glory Album|Open Door (See You Later)]]’ and ‘[[The Glory Album|Ft. Knox]]’ as ‘Best of the Week’ singles back to back. As well, TGA received key placements on [[Amazon Music]], [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Tidal (service)|TIDAL]], and [[Spotify]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christongray.com/promo/|title=PROMO|website=CHRISTON GRAY|access-date=2016-09-14}}</ref>
[[The Glory Album]] was released on March 11, 2016. The LP went on to again claim the #5 position on the [[Billboard R&B charts]], while also hitting #6 on the Christian chart.
Gray was chosen as the first ever Youth Ambassador<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rapzilla.com/rz/news/38-backstage/13666-christon-gray-was-first-ever-youth-ambassador-at-the-bet-awards|title=Christon Gray was First Ever Youth Ambassador at the BET Awards|last=Sarachik|first=Justin|work=Rapzilla.com|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en-US}}</ref> for the [[BET Awards]] in June 2016.
After just one album with the label, Gray let fans know that he had officially left RCA in January 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christongray.com/|title=HOME|website=CHRISTON GRAY|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-24}}</ref> He did not elaborate on the reasons, but said when the time was right he would speak about it. According to the post, it was a business decision and he wishes all parties involved well.
=== 2017 - No Hesitation and Return to FYS/RCA Records === In March 2017, Gray, along with Chris Shaban started their own Podcast entitled 'Chris' Podcast'. The first two episodes included guests [[Ty Montgomery]], [[Chris Broussard]] and [[Darren M. Haynes|Darren Haynes]]. Gray mentioned that this was a pilot program and that they were looking to bring it back sometime in 2019.
On July 28, Gray dropped a single called 'No Hesitation' independently. This was his first release since leaving Fo Yo Soul/RCA Records. In an interview with Wade-O, Gray said, "You know the inspiration for the song came from me watching the BET Awards, and I saw 'Crae's speech, and I know he caught some flack for that... I talked to Lecrae the other day, and I told him, I come from that world... I grew up listening to them and without them, you (Wade) would not be having an interview with me... so I told him (Lecrae), yo, I didn't expect you to go back and apologize, so I did it for you.<ref>{{Citation|last=The Wade-O Radio Video Channel|title=Christon Gray on Story Behind "No Hesitation", Leaving RCA, and More|date=2017-08-07|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wRy3B3VmH6E|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref>" The song would become another hit for Gray, and he went on to perform it live at the 2018 [[Stellar Awards]].
A week later, on August 4th, he released 'Shoulda Known', which included a sample of his song, '[[School of Roses|Burning House (Roses 102)]]' off the School of Roses album<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BXi0W19hyaG/?taken-by=christongray|title=Christon Gray on Instagram: “My 2nd single 'Shoulda Known' featuring my brother @pray4jgivens is now available to stream worldwide. I've heard from a lot of School of…”|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref>. It featured long-time collaborator and friend, [[JGivens]].
On Sunday November 5, Christon Gray was announced as the new Worship Leader at Christ's Church in [[Mason, Ohio]].<ref><iframe src="https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fccmasoncampus%2Fvideos%2F2111942965486135%2F&show_text=0&width=560" width="560" height="315" style="border:none;overflow:hidden" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowTransparency="true" allowFullScreen="true"></iframe></ref>
By the end of the year, an agreement had been reached for him to rejoin Fo Yo Soul and the new staff at [[RCA Inspiration]] in Nashville. It would not become public until later on in 2018<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rapzilla.com/2018-10-christon-gray-rapzilla-chris-chicago-ep-115/|title=Christon Gray on Rapzilla.com LIVE with Chris Chicago - Ep. 115|website=rapzilla.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref>.
=== 2018 - Clear The Heir === By the end of 2017 and leading into 2018, Gray let fans know that he was back writing, but did not elaborate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BcnRz4dh58O/?taken-by=christongray|title=Christon Gray on Instagram: “WRITING // 2018”|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref> There weren't anymore indications until a post on Instagram in February with Chris Shaban and Ty Montgomery, taken from a writing session in [[Cambridge, Ontario]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BfUDkEXBEhF/?taken-by=christongray|title=Christon Gray on Instagram: “All Amour”|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref>He would later go on to tell that 4 songs were already written by this point, with two making the album, 'Seekrets' and 'Together Forever'.
In March, there came a string of posts from the studio that included MD and producer Marlo Scott, Producer GiAngelo Power, Pastor Trevor DeVage, Montgomery and Shaban. Gray said in a post on Twitter, "...there was a week in March 2018 when everything started to come together. That week we did 'Grow Up', 'You & I (Sampson's Lament)' and brushed up a few other songs that made the cut."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/christongray/status/1048606296893808646|title=Christon Gray on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-10-06|language=en}}</ref> Those other songs were 'Seekrets', 'Together Forever' and the instrumental to 'Clear The Heir'.
In April at the Stellar Awards, rumors started swirling that Christon had re-signed with Fo Yo Soul/RCA Records, and while it had happened months before, it was a post with Kirk Franklin that said "Welcome home" that started the buzz.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BhhiF08l83q/?taken-by=christongray|title=Christon Gray on Instagram: “Welcome home”|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref> One more studio picture that month and Gray took some time off of his social media and no further updates came until late in the summer.
On August 2, a post from famed Canadian studio [[Metalworks Studios|Metalworks]] that read "October 19" and had no sound, but a studio full of his collaborators started his promotion run for the album.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Bl_-DvdgWoM/?taken-by=christongray|title=Christon Gray on Instagram: “October 19”|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref>It would come to light later on that October 19 would be the release date for the album.
On August 24, he dropped the first single 'Together Forever' with credit going to Fo Yo Soul/Essential Sound/Sony. The track contained a portion of his September 2016 interview on Sirius XM's 'Sway In The Morning' where he discussed divorce.
On September 14, he released the albums second single 'Time Out', produced by Toronto's GiAngelo Power. That instrumental had come from a writing session with JGivens in November 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/christongray/status/1048612615449186304|title=Christon Gray on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-10-06|language=en}}</ref>
On September 21, RCA released the music video for 'Time Out' and it featured a host of Christian athletes including Ty Montgomery, [[Mike Conley Jr.|Mike Conley]], [[A.J. Styles]], [[Steven Souza Jr.|Steven Sousa Jr]]., [[Andre Ward]], [[Michelle Plouffe]] and more. The songs co-writer and video director, Chris Shaban said, "Growing up as a Christian kid (in Toronto), I was always inspired by athletes who excelled at a high level and love Jesus, so we decided we'd like to try and motivate the next generation the same way." It was accompanied by the #TimeOutChallenge that asked fans to rap over the songs instrumental with the winner receiving a signed pair of [[Air Jordan|Jordan Brand]] shoes from Conley and a signed [[Green Bay Packers]] jersey from Montgomery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BohDzU_B6S9/?taken-by=christongray|title=Christon Gray on Instagram: “Listen to my boy @mac11 aka ‘Captain Clutch’ and join the #TimeOutChallenge right now. His signed Jordan’s and @ty_kingdomcitizen signed…”|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref>
On October 12, Gray released the third single from the album, 'Grow Up'. It was immediately added to numerous playlists on [[Spotify]], including 'New Music Friday', 'New Music Friday Christian', 'Blessings', and 'The Flow'.
