revision.text:
{{More footnotes|date=October 2017}} {{About|the Cajun/Creole healer}} In Louisiana, the term '''traiteur''' (sometimes spelled ''treateur'') describes a man or woman (a ''traiteuse'') who practises what is sometimes called [[faith healing]]. A '''traiteur''' is Native Creole healer or a traditional healer of the French-speaking [[Houma Tribe]], whose primary method of treatment involves using the [[laying on of hands]]. An important part of Creole folk religion, the traiteur combines [[Catholic]] prayer and medicinal remedies. They are called to treat a variety of ailments, including: [[earache]]s, [[toothache]]s, [[wart]]s, [[tumor]]s, [[angina]], and [[bleeding]]. In the past, they substituted for trained physicians in remote rural areas of [[Acadiana]]. Most traiteurs consider their healing abilities a gift from God, and therefore refuse to accept payment in exchange for their services.
Traiteurism is a very old tradition that is dying out, and very few traiteurs now exist. Traditionally, the rituals of the traiteur are passed down to the opposite gender. So a male must pass it down to a female, and vice versa. The traiteur must be asked to perform the treatments and will rarely offer them outright unless the need is great, and they can not ask for a payment of any kind, although it is acceptable to accept gifts for treating a person. However gifts for a true traiteur are never required.
In Southern Louisiana, the co-existence of conventional medicine and traiteurs offers patients a range of resources for treating illness. Traiteurs and their patients do not view the two systems as conflicting. For example, if treating someone with a Coup-de-Soleil, or sunstroke, one would perform the ritual, then have the patient drink as much water as they could while lying down and then wiping the patient with a towel dampened in cool water. When a traiteur becomes ill, he goes to the doctor, yet he also employs week-long ceremonial candles (which are highly commercialized), Catholic [[Novenas]] (a Catholic rite involving nine days or weeks of recitation of a series of prayers), native traditional herbs, and perhaps a visit by another traiteur to get well. Some will use herbal remedies if they are known, the herbal remedies begin to cross over into [[Louisiana Voodoo|voodoo]] being that both originated with the Creole people. Switching from one healing system to another is common among these practitioners and their patients, whose religious syncretism is matched by [[syncretism]] among medical systems. Another example of this fluidity is evident in the language with which the patients label their illnesses. Lousay A., a healer, is shown at his weekly home "clinic" hours one Saturday treating patients. One woman describes her condition as ''la mal angle'', Louisiana French for [[shingles]], while another woman explains that she has ''herpes zoster," the medical term for the virus. Even in language, the traditional and the biomedical is heard to exist side by side without conflict.
The rituals involved with traiteurism are simple and time-honored, and they are careful to not transgress the teachings of the Catholic Church. The methods of the traiteurs are purported to be able to work on a person regardless of faith, should one be so moved as to ask for a treatment.
==In popular culture== {{Unreferenced section|date=October 2017}} * In the ''[[Band of Brothers (TV miniseries)|Band of Brothers]]'' episode "Bastogne", Cajun medic Eugene Roe tells fellow medic Ralph Spina that his grandmother was a traiteuse. This detail was invented for the show and has no basis in the real Eugene Roe's family history. * A video game of the same name is being created by Raconteur Games, though it does not specifically focus on Cajun folklore.
==See also== * [[Louisiana Creole people]] * [[Houma people]]
==References==
* Acadian to Cajun: Transformation of a People, 1803-1877. Brasseaux, Carl A. Jackson, Miss.: University Press of Mississippi, 1992. * The Cajuns: From Acadia to Louisiana. Rushton, William Faulkner. New York: Farrar Straus Giroux, 1979 * Cajun Country. Barry Jean Ancelet, Jay Edwards, Glen Pitre, et al. Jackson, Miss.: University Press of Mississippi, 1991.
==External links==
* [http://library.louisiana.edu/Spec/traiteur.shtml University of Louisiana Library: Traiteurs] * [http://rahalmaitretraiteur.com/ Traiteur oriental pour Mariage] * [http://www.louisianafolklife.org/Resources/main_prog_streaming_video.html Louisianafolklife.org Streaming Audio and Video] * [http://www.lpb.org/programs/traiteurs/ Documentary on modern-day Traiteurs]
[[Category:Cajun culture]] [[Category:Faith healers]] [[Category:Traditional healthcare occupations]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox military person | name = William Henry Muir Lowe | image = | image_size = | caption = | nickname = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1861|10|20|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[North-Western Provinces]], [[British Raj|British India]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1944|02|07|1861|10|20|df=yes}} | death_place = [[London]], [[England]] | placeofburial = | allegiance = {{flag|United Kingdom}} | branch = {{army|United Kingdom}} | serviceyears = 1881–1907
1914–1919 | rank = [[Major-General (United Kingdom)|Major-General]] | unit = [[7th Dragoon Guards]] | commands = 3rd Reserve Cavalry Brigade | battles = [[1882 Anglo-Egyptian War]]
[[Third Anglo-Burmese War]]
[[Second Boer War]]
[[World War I|First World War]]
[[Easter Rising]] | awards = [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]]
[[Mentioned in Despatches]] | relations = | laterwork = }} [[Major-General]] '''William Henry Muir "W. H. M." Lowe''', [[Order of the Bath|CB]] (20 October 1861 – 7 February 1944) was a [[British Army]] officer who commanded the British forces in [[Dublin]] during the [[Easter Rising]] of 1916 and received the surrender of the [[Irish republicanism|Irish republican]] forces. ==Early Life and career== Lowe was born in [[North-Western Provinces]], [[British Raj|India]], to William Henry Lowe of the [[Indian Civil Service]], and Caroline Charlotte Muir. He was educated at the [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst|Royal Military College, Sandhurst]], and commissioned in the [[7th Dragoon Guards]] as a [[Lieutenant (British Army and Royal Marines)|lieutenant]] on 22 October 1881.{{London Gazette|issue=25029|page=5191|date=1881-10-21}} The following year he saw action in the [[1882 Anglo-Egyptian War|Egyptian Campaign]], where the 7th Dragoon Guards were part of the 1st Cavalry Brigade led by General Sir [[Baker Russell]]. Lowe was involved in the fighting at [[Kassassin]], the [[Battle of Tel el-Kebir]] and the march on [[Cairo]].Obituary: Maj.-Gen. W.H.M. Lowe, ''The Times'', 9 February 1944, p. 7.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZEUaAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA142&lpg=RA1-PA142&dq=7th+Dragoon+Guards+lowe&source=bl&ots=PrTxSW5sEs&sig=Sv8N9h3S1YROLqj9e2LUYaCkVT8&hl=en&ei=9t_VSdfAFp6qjAfNssjzDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6 Hart's Annual Army List, Militia List, and Imperial Yeomanry List for 1888] He received the [[Egypt Medal]] and the [[Khedive's Star]], a medal presented by [[Tewfik Pasha|Khedive Tawfiq]] to all officers and men engaged in the campaign.{{cite book |title=[[Who's Who (UK)#Who Was Who|Who Was Who]], Vol. IV: 1941–1950 |last= |first= |authorlink= |edition=fifth |year=1980 |publisher=A and C Black |location=London |isbn=0-7136-2131-1 |page=701|url= }} In 1886, Lowe went to [[Burma]] from India, where the 7th Dragoon Guards were stationed, as a special service officer to the Upper Burma Task Force during the guerrilla phase of the [[Third Anglo-Burmese War]]. Remaining in Burma until 1887, he received the [[India General Service Medal (1854)|India General Service Medal]] with two [[Medal bar|clasps]]. He was promoted to the rank of [[Captain (BARM)|captain]] on 9 March 1887 and [[Major (British Army)|major]] on 2 March 1892.Hart′s Army list, 1903 ==Second Boer War== On 19 September 1899, he was promoted to [[Lieutenant-colonel (British Army)|lieutenant-colonel]] and assumed command of the 7th Dragoon Guards. The regiment embarked the [[SS Armenian|SS ''Armenian'']] in [[Southampton]] on 8 February 1900, and departed for service in [[South Africa]], with Lowe in command of the men on the ship.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The War - Embarcation of Troops |day_of_week=Friday |date=9 February 1900 |page_number=6 |issue=36061| }} From 1900 to 1902, he led the regiment in the [[Second Boer War]], being present at the capture of [[Pretoria]] and the [[Battle of Diamond Hill]], and was promoted [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] colonel in November 1900.[http://pinetreeweb.com/conan-doyle-chapter-28.htm Arthur Conan Doyle, The Great Boer War. London, Smith, Elder & Co., 1902] [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Lord Kitchener's]] despatch of 8 August 1901 related how "at midnight on the 30th July Colonel Lowe, 7th Dragoon Guards, successfully surprised a farmhouse, from which he took 11 armed prisoners with rifles, bandoliers and horses."{{London Gazette|issue=27377|page=7371|date=1901-11-15}} Lowe was twice more [[Mentioned in Despatches]]: in [[Frederick Roberts, 1st Earl Roberts|Lord Roberts']] Recommendations, 2 April 1901 and in Lord Kitchener's Final Despatch, 23 June 1902.{{cite web |url=http://www.angloboerwar.com/Other/army_mentions.htm |title=Mentions in Despatches - Army |accessdate=2009-04-01 |work= |publisher=Anglo Boer War.com |date=2004–2009 }}{{London Gazette|issue=27459|page=4838|date=1902-07-29}} He received both the [[Queen's South Africa Medal|Queen's]] and [[King's South Africa Medal]]. Following the end of the war in June 1902 he returned home on the SS ''Galeka'' which arrived in Southampton in October 1902.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The Army in South Africa - Troops returning home| day_of_week=Wednesday |date=24 September 1902 |page_number=7 |issue=36881}} He left the 7th Dragoon Guards in March 1903 to become Assistant Quartermaster-General of the [[II Corps (United Kingdom)|II Corps]] ([[British Commands and Army groups|Southern Command]]), being promoted to full colonel. In May 1905, he went to the Northern Command as colonel in charge of cavalry records and staff officer for the [[Imperial Yeomanry]]. He was made a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in 1906.{{London Gazette|issue=27926|supp=y|page=4460|date=1906-06-29}} He went on half-pay in March 1907 and retired a year later. ==Easter Rising== On the outbreak of the [[World War I|First World War]] in 1914, Lowe rejoined the army as Inspector of Cavalry, and was appointed as a Brigade Commander with rank of [[Brigadier-General]] in 1915. He was commander of the 3rd Reserve Cavalry Brigade, stationed at the [[Curragh Camp]], at the outbreak of the [[Easter Rising]] on Monday, 24 April 1916. On being informed of the Rising by phone, he ordered the brigade to Dublin by train.{{cite book |title=Easter Rising 1916: Birth of the Irish Republic |last=McNally |first=Michael |authorlink= |author2=Peter Dennis |year=2007 |publisher=Osprey Publishing |location= |isbn=978-1-84603-067-3 |pages=20, 47 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X_LY5lZ62w8C}} Arriving himself at [[Dublin Heuston railway station|Kingsbridge railway station]] in the early hours of Tuesday morning, Lowe assumed command of British forces in Dublin and set about securing the line between the station, [[Dublin Castle]] and [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]], thus dividing the rebel positions north and south of the river.{{cite book |title=Easter 1916: The Irish Rebellion |last=Townshend |first=Charles |authorlink=Charles Townshend (historian) |year=2006 |publisher=Penguin Books |location=London |isbn=978-0-14-101216-2 |page=186 |pages= |url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=xZzIAQAACAAJ }} It was Lowe who ordered the shelling of [[Liberty Hall]] by field guns from Trinity College, and who ordered the Sherwood Foresters to continue advancing on Mount Street Bridge with a high cost in casualties.McNally 2007, pp. 68, 71 On Saturday, 29 April, after being approached by Nurse [[Elizabeth O'Farrell]], he agreed to negotiate with the leaders only if they would [[Unconditional surrender|surrender unconditionally]], and at 2.30 pm that day, accompanied by Nurse O'Farrell, [[Patrick Pearse]] surrendered to Lowe.McNally 2007, p. 88 He was awarded the honorary rank of major-general when he finally retired in March 1919. ==Personal life== Lowe married, in 1895, Frances Broster (died 29 September 1942), the widow of Captain Robert Harry Johnson of the 64th Foot Regiment and daughter of Francisco de Salvo, of Salerno, Sicily.''Genealogists' Magazine'', vol.27, no.7, Society of Genealogists, London, 2002, pps:332-326, "Another Englishman Abroad - John Loder and Hedy Lamarr" by Charles Kidd, editor of ''Debrett's Peerage & Baronetage''. They had a son, and a daughter Elizabeth, who became a nun. Their son, [[John Loder (actor)|John]], was a British Army officer who with his father also took part in the suppression of the Rising and accepting the surrender of Pearse[http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/easterrising/gallery/gallery06.shtml BBC, 1916 Easter Rising Gallery] —fought at [[Gallipoli Campaign|Gallipoli]] and [[Battle of the Somme|the Somme]] and subsequently became a Hollywood actor under the screen name John Loder.{{cite web |url=http://www.irishplayography.com/search/play.asp?play_id=2401 |title=Hedy Lamarr and the Easter Rising |accessdate=2009-03-30 |work= |publisher=Irish Theatre Institute |date=17 August 2006 }} General Lowe died in [[London]] on 7 February 1944, aged 82. Neither an otherwise comprehensive obituary in ''[[The Times]]'' nor an entry in ''[[Who's Who (UK)#Who Was Who|Who Was Who]]'' 1941–1950 made reference to his role in the Easter Rising, although it is mentioned in John Loder's autobiography, and there is a photograph of Pearse surrendering to him.''Hollywood Hussar'' by John Loder, London, 1977, {{ISBN|0-7030-0121-3}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4594388.stm BBC News report on the unconditional surrender document] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/easterrising/gallery/gallery06.shtml Photograph of Lowe taking the surrender of Pearse] {{Easter Rising}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lowe, William}} [[Category:1861 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:British Army cavalry generals of World War I]] [[Category:British Army personnel of the Anglo-Egyptian War]] [[Category:British Army personnel of the Second Boer War]] [[Category:British military personnel of the Third Anglo-Burmese War]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:7th Dragoon Guards officers]] [[Category:Graduates of the Royal Military College, Sandhurst]] [[Category:People of the Easter Rising]] [[Category:Imperial Yeomanry officers]]
